subject: Re: [junit] Re: Dynamically adding test classes at test-time
msgSnippet: ... You can actually give pass Suite a null for the parent class, and then a list of subclasses. ... Yes. ... The division between 1) Discover / Declare Tests
messageBody:
On Thu, May 14, 2009 at 5:44 PM, Miles Parker <milesparker@...> wrote:
>
> Hi David and Johannes,
>
> NP. It does Â sound a little scary -- at some point you get into "why
> not roll my own" territory, which is a dangerous way to be thinking!
>
> I remember know that I did look at using Runner before but it wasn't
> clear how to get back into the core functionality once I'd implemented
> my own. I was looking at BlockJUnit4ClassRunner which sounds like its
> not what I want. Its still looking pretty complex to me even after
> looking at the SuiteRunner code but maybe I'm just having a slow brain
> day. But it doesn't look like I can use inheirit from Suite or Parent
> Runner for example because they both are looking for a class.

You can actually give pass Suite a null for the parent class, and then
a list of subclasses.

> "A runner that creates a suite from a set of names should be
> straightforward given you can compute the number of tests beforehand,
> eg. because the class can already be loaded or you know the names of
> test methods per class from some other source."

> I think one question is the key make or break though -- does JUnit
> expect to traverse the entire test tree before running any tests?

Yes.

> The
> reason I ask is because the above is not quite true -- I don't
> actually know the names of the test methods at runtime, or at lest I'd
> like to obtain them from the generated classes. To simplify down to
> brass tasks, what I basically need to do is use JUnit exactly the same
> way, except to substitute just one set of nodes in the test traversal
> tree -- for class discovery to load the classes by name.

The division between

1) Discover / Declare Tests
2) Run Tests

is unlikely to change any time soon.

> But the trick
> of course is that needs to be deferred until test run-time.

Does the test discovery step _need_ to happen inside a test computation? Why?

I have a feeling we have a mismatch of assumptions.

David Saff
